Various conditions affecting the tympanum (like middle ear effusion, infection, or ossicular chain problems) can cause hearing loss and sometimes non-pulsatile tinnitus, but pulsatile tinnitus points towards a vascular issue. D. Cholesteatoma: A cholesteatoma is an abnormal skin growth in the middle ear behind the eardrum. It's often associated with chronic ear infections and can cause conductive hearing loss, ear drainage, and sometimes non-pulsatile tinnitus or dizziness. Pulsatile tinnitus is not a typical feature of cholesteatoma.

questions.text: A patient with prolonged intubation complains of respiratory distress. Study the given endoscopic image and choose the staging used in the suspected diagnosis .
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) COTTON MYER. Let's break down why: The endoscopic image, showing subglottic stenosis (a narrowing of the airway below the vocal cords), in a patient with a history of prolonged intubation strongly suggests post-intubation subglottic stenosis. The Cotton-Myer grading system is the most widely used and accepted classification system specifically designed for pediatric and adult subglottic stenosis. It grades the severity of the stenosis based on the percentage of airway obstruction visualized during endoscopy. This staging is crucial for guiding management decisions, including the need for surgical intervention and the type of procedure. Incorrect Answer Explanations: A. TNM: The TNM staging system is primarily used for classifying malignant tumors, including those of the larynx and trachea. It describes the extent of the primary tumor (T), the presence or absence of regional lymph node metastasis (N), and the presence or absence of distant metastasis (M). It is not applicable to benign conditions like post-intubation subglottic stenosis. C. FISCH: The Fisch classification is used for staging temporal bone tumors, particularly glomus tumors. It describes the extent of the tumor based on its involvement of different structures within the temporal bone and surrounding areas. It is not relevant to subglottic stenosis. D. AJCC (American Joint Committee on Cancer): The AJCC staging system is a comprehensive system for staging various types of cancer, including head and neck cancers. While it might have some general guidelines for airway tumors, the Cotton-Myer system is far more specific and relevant for classifying the severity of benign subglottic stenosis, especially in the context of post-intubation injury.

choices.text: Head turned to left and eyeball moves to left with nystagmus
Head turned to left and eyeball moves to right with nystagmus
Head turned to right and eyeball moves to left with nystagmus
Head turned to right and eyeball moves to right with nystagmus

questions.text: 45 yrs old female diagnosed right vestibular neuronitis, what will be the finding in head impulse test?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Head turned to right and eyeball moves to left with nystagmus. Let's break down why: Vestibular neuronitis is an inflammation of the vestibular nerve, one of the branches of the vestibulocochlear nerve responsible for balance. In this case, the right vestibular nerve is affected. The head impulse test (HIT) assesses the function of the semicircular canals, which detect angular head movements. Here's how it works in the context of right vestibular neuronitis: The Pathology: The damaged right vestibular nerve will send weaker or inaccurate signals to the brain about head movement, specifically when the head is rapidly turned to the right. The Brain's Interpretation: The brain perceives this weaker signal as if the head hasn't moved enough to the right. The Reflexive Eye Movement (VOR): The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) normally works to keep the eyes fixed on a target during head movement. When the head is turned quickly to the right, a healthy VOR would cause the eyes to move equally and oppositely (to the left) to maintain gaze. The Impaired Response: Because the right vestibular nerve isn't functioning correctly, the initial compensatory eye movement to the left will be insufficient when the head is thrust to the right. The eyes will initially lag behind the head movement, appearing to move with the head towards the right. The Corrective Saccade: To refixate on the target, the brain will then generate a rapid, jerky eye movement in the opposite direction of the head movement – a corrective saccade to the left. This saccade is what the examiner observes. Therefore, in a patient with right vestibular neuronitis, when the head is rapidly turned to the right (the side of the lesion), the eyes will initially move with the head and then make a corrective saccade to the left to regain focus. This indicates a deficit in the right vestibular nerve function. Let's look at why the other options are incorrect: A. Head turned to left and eyeball moves to left with nystagmus: This would be the expected finding if the left vestibular nerve were impaired. The corrective saccade would be towards the right. B. Head turned to left and eyeball moves to right with nystagmus: This scenario doesn't align with the expected compensatory eye movements in response to head thrusts. D. Head turned to right and eyeball moves to right with nystagmus: This would suggest the eyes are moving in the same direction as the head thrust, indicating a severe dysfunction of the VOR on the tested side (right), followed by a corrective saccade in the same direction, which is not how the reflex works. The corrective saccade always opposes the direction of the head movement.

questions.text: A patient complaing of chronic nasal obstruction since last 6 months was operated 2 months back and now present with crusts and bleeding. Study the nasal examination image and comment on the surgery which was done?"
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Based on the likely appearance of the nasal examination image (which I cannot see directly, but inferring from the symptoms of crusting and bleeding post-surgery for chronic nasal obstruction), the surgery most likely performed was (A) SMR (Submucosal Resection). Let's break down why: Submucosal Resection (SMR) is a surgical procedure aimed at correcting a deviated nasal septum to improve airflow and relieve nasal obstruction. It involves raising the mucoperichondrial and mucoperiosteal flaps on either side of the septum and then removing the underlying deviated cartilage and bone. While it can effectively improve nasal breathing, SMR is known to sometimes result in a larger raw mucosal surface within the nasal cavity compared to septoplasty. This increased exposed area can be prone to postoperative crusting and bleeding as the mucosa heals. The symptoms of chronic nasal obstruction followed by postoperative crusting and bleeding are consistent with the recovery phase after an SMR. Incorrect Answer Explanations: B. Septoplasty: Septoplasty also aims to correct a deviated nasal septum but typically involves a more precise reshaping and repositioning of the cartilage and bone rather than extensive resection. It often involves less disruption of the mucosal lining compared to SMR, potentially leading to less postoperative crusting and bleeding. C. FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery): FESS is a minimally invasive procedure performed entirely through the nostrils using endoscopes to address sinus disease. It focuses on widening the sinus drainage pathways and does not directly involve extensive resection of the nasal septum that would typically lead to significant crusting and bleeding in the anterior nasal cavity. D. Caldwell-Luc: The Caldwell-Luc procedure is an older surgical approach to access the maxillary sinus through an incision in the upper gingivobuccal sulcus. It does not directly address the nasal septum and would not typically result in the kind of crusting and bleeding seen in the anterior nasal cavity following surgery for nasal obstruction.

questions.text: A patient presents with nasal trauma following a road traffic accident. Lateral X-ray of the nasal bone shows a displaced nasal bone fracture.Which instrument is commonly used for reduction of nasal bone fracture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Walsham forceps Sol:- Explanation: Walsham forceps: Used for lateral nasal bone fracture reduction. Asch forceps: Specifically used for septal fracture reduction. Killian’s speculum: Used for nasal cavity examination, not fracture reduction. Septal elevator: Used for elevating mucoperichondrium during septal surgery.

questions.text: A man 50 years of age present with tinnitus, ear fullness and hearing loss in his right ear. Seven years later, he began to experience vertigo, headache, and progressive loss of balance. After 2 years, audiometry showed moderate sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear that has not been investigated. On HPE slide Antoni A and Antoni B cells were seen. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Vestibular schwannoma Sol:- Acoustic Neuromas (Vestibular Schwannomas) and Other Cerebellopontine Angle Tumors Acoustic Neuroma Histologic Types 1. Antoni Type A: histologically parallel nuclei, uniform spindle cells, compact cells 2. Antoni Type B: histologically less uniform, may have fatty or hyaline degeneration, less cellular Symptoms: • Progressive, asymmetric, high-tone hearing loss (most common presenting symptom); Tinnitus; • Vertigo or imbalance; • Advanced tumors may present with facial nerve (Hitselberger’s sign, reduced • sensation of the EAC and conchal bowl) • Trigeminal nerve involvement • Lower cranial nerve involvement, Diagnosis Audiometry: initial screening, asymmetric hearing loss Auditory Brainstem Response: most sensitive and specific audiological test (10–15?lse negative rate), may be used for selective screening asymmetrical hearing loss or vestibular weakness • MRI with gadolinium: enhances best imaging study, sensitive to tumors >2 mm, brightly enhance with gadolinium • CT with contrast: indicated if MRI is unavailable or contraindicated,may miss tumors smaller than 10 mm, suspect with asymmetric widening of the internal auditory canal Management

questions.text: A patient present with ear discharge and hearing loss. Otoscopic examination shown below Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) MRM Sol:- Let’s Dissect each option a. MRM (Modified Radical Mastoidectomy) Indicated in chronic suppurative otitis media – cholesteatoma Otoscopy usually shows attic perforation or cholesteatoma debris b. Myringoplasty Indicated in dry central perforation without infection Not performed in active discharge c. Atticotomy Performed for limited attic cholesteatoma Used if disease is confined to attic only d. Exploratory tympanotomy Done for sensorineural hearing loss or conductive loss with intact TM to explore ossicular pathology

choices.text: Ligation of sphenopalatine artery via endoscopic approach

questions.text: A 60-year-old male, a known case of chronic hypertension and diabetes mellitus, presents with severe epistaxis. Initial methods of controlling the epistaxis, including anterior and posterior nasal packing, have failed.What is the next best step in management, and which artery should be ligated?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ligation of sphenopalatine artery via endoscopic approach Sol:- In refractory posterior epistaxis, after conservative measures fail: Endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (SPAL) is the standard next step. Sphenopalatine artery is the terminal branch of maxillary artery, which supplies the posterior nasal cavity.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with progressive nasal obstruction and recurrent episodes of epistaxis. On imaging, a vascular mass is seen occupying the nasopharynx and extending to the pterygopalatine fossa with pressure over the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma Sol:- Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma • Age & Gender: Typically affects adolescent males (second decade). Symptoms: Recurrent epistaxis, nasal obstruction. • Imaging Finding: Extension into pterygopalatine fossa may cause anterior bowing of posterior wall of maxilla – Holman-Miller sign. • Nature: Benign but highly vascular tumor ? biopsy is avoided due to risk of severe bleeding.

questions.text: A patient present with hearing loss.On examination rinnes negative on left side and positive on right side .Weber was lateralized to left side. Choose most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Left Conductive Deafness Sol:- • The most appropriate diagnosis for a patient presenting with a negative Rinne test on the left side, a positive Rinne test on the right side, and a Weber test lateralized to the left is unilateral conductive hearing loss in the left ear

questions.text: Enlarged orange tonsils as shown in image is found in :-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Tangier disease Sol:- • In tangier disease there is a DEFECT IN EFFLUX OF CELLULAR CHOLESTEROL, leading to cholesterol accumulation in reticuloendothelial cells. • ENLARGE ORANGE TONSILS are pathognomonic of tangier disease.

choices.text: Topical antibiotics should be treatment of choice

questions.text: Choose the most appropriate statement regarding orbital complication of sinusitis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ethmoidal sinusitis is most common Sol:- Ethmoidal sinusitis is the most common cause of orbital complications due to the thin lamina papyracea separating the ethmoid sinus from the orbit. Topical antibiotics are not sufficient in orbital complications; systemic antibiotics and sometimes surgical drainage are required. Both anterior and posterior walls can be involved depending on the extent. Restricted ocular movements and proptosis are common in orbital cellulitis or abscess.

questions.text: A 55 year old patient comes with hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma and surgical management was done. The post operative image of the patient is given below. Which of the following surgery was done on this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Total laryngectomy Sol:- • Total laryngectomy indicated for T3 and T4 cases. • Post-op, the airway and alimentary tract are permanently separated. • The patient breathes through a permanent tracheal stoma — no air passes through nose/mouth.
